stream_context.summary: While feeling ill, Kaze worked on the central hub of the overworld. The stream was dominated by two main events: a technical crisis where a full hard drive halted his progress, and a design breakthrough where he solved a creative block by realizing he was trying to merge two older, separate map concepts.

development_findings.summary: The game's original overworld was entirely scrapped and is being replaced with a new, massive version designed to be a single, seamless level.
development_findings.quote: The original overworld is completely erased. It's just not up to the quality standards.

development_findings.summary: A previous SSD failure resulted in the loss of un-backed-up work, including old hack code and project documentation.
Kaze is highly critical of the original Mario 64 engine, describing its code as inefficient and a hindrance to development.
development_findings.quote: Whenever someone tells you that programmers used to be better back in the day, just show them the Mario 64 engine code.

development_findings.summary: The project is estimated to be approximately 10% complete, with the current ROM size just under 60MB.
Kaze's custom engine enhancements have solved the 'thin invisible walls' problem present in the original Mario 64.
He is actively seeking playtesters for individual courses, such as Course 11, to gather feedback and data.
Another contributor, ESA, is currently working on a side level for the game.
A design block involving a flat, uninteresting beach was resolved when Kaze realized the area's awkwardness stemmed from his attempt to merge two previously separate map concepts.
Multiplayer is a feature Kaze would like to add and believes wouldn't be too difficult, but it is not a priority due to expected 'jank' with elements like boss fights.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes modern AAA games are too safe and advocates for more 'risky' and creative games, citing the original Yoshi's Island as a key inspiration.
context_findings.quote: You like Mario well fuck it use this do you just write on Yoshi now the whole game. That's the type of shit I want to see.

context_findings.summary: He expresses deep frustration with technical maintenance on computers, contrasting it with the creative freedom he feels when building his own systems in game development.
context_findings.quote: With computers you're just learning about things someone else made. You have to deal with someone else's systems. It's not like you're making new systems, you know. That's what I do.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is actively seeking sponsorships and creating sponsored content to financially support his family, indicating that his YouTube presence is his primary livelihood.
context_findings.quote: I gotta make money for my family.

context_findings.summary: He explicitly stated he will not create and sell physical cartridges of the game due to legal issues with Nintendo, and plans to release it for free online.
Kaze shared his personal philosophy on parenting, believing in being more transparent with children about difficult topics.
context_findings.quote: I think children are a lot more emotionally ready to hear uncomfortable truths than we give them credit for.

context_findings.summary: He expressed disappointment that his efforts to generate revenue from posting on Twitter had completely failed.
Kaze streamed while feeling sick and feverish, which impacted his energy and mood throughout the session.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided real-time feedback in the chat, pointing out a symmetry error Kaze had made in a room in Course 2.

zeina.summary: Zeina's concept art for a cave entrance was considered for the overworld but ultimately not used for the current design direction.
Kaze revealed a playful personal dynamic with Zeina, referencing an inside joke about a 'wasabi song' he created.
zeina.quote: Can we all do a deal the next time you see Zaina tell her that the wasabi song is actually like really good. I invented the wasabi song in the car today, and she won't believe it's good.

key_stories.title: The Full Hard Drive Crisis
key_stories.summary: A technical issue completely halted development when Kaze's full hard drive prevented him from opening essential files. The stream became a live troubleshooting session, revealing his frustration with technical maintenance versus creative work and highlighting his reliance on his community for solutions.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze's primary hard drive (C:) was full, which prevented him from opening a large Photoshop file essential for his development work, bringing the stream to a halt.
key_stories.process: Kaze spent a significant portion of the stream troubleshooting the issue live. He systematically deleted old programs, searched for Adobe cache files, and ran Windows disk cleanup utilities, all while vocalizing his frustration with technical maintenance.
key_stories.outcome: After trying numerous suggestions from his chat and deleting old programs, he freed just enough space to open the file. The incident prompted a donation for a new SSD, which he plans to install to prevent the issue from recurring.
key_stories.key_quote: I find computers very frustrating to deal with, so I don't really deal with computers. With computers you're just learning about things someone else made.

key_stories.title: Fixing the Boring Beach
key_stories.summary: Kaze faced a creative block with a dull beach area in the overworld. After struggling for ideas, he had a moment of clarity, realizing the area's poor design stemmed from merging two older map concepts. This insight unlocked his creative process, allowing him to redesign the space into a central hub with purpose.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze was creatively stuck while designing a large, flat, and visually uninteresting beach area in the central overworld hub, calling it 'depressing and sad'.
key_stories.process: After brainstorming minor additions failed to solve the core problem, Kaze had a moment of clarity. He remembered that the awkward layout was a result of him trying to merge two older, separate map concepts (Part 5 and Part 7) into one.
key_stories.outcome: This realization allowed him to redesign the space with a clear purpose, fusing the areas and beginning to populate it with level entrances and brainstormed features like a sandcastle obstacle course, turning it into a functional hub.
key_stories.key_quote: What happened is this whole bottom area here was supposed to be a different area. That's why this sucks so much. Now it all makes sense.

open_questions.context: Biobak provided real-time design feedback in the chat, and Kaze mentioned another contributor, ESA, is working on a side level. This suggests a distributed, asynchronous collaboration style.
questions: How does the team typically collaborate and give feedback? Is it mostly through Discord, live streams, or other methods?
What is the process for integrating work from other contributors like ESA?
How do you manage creative differences or conflicting ideas with key contributors like Biobak or Zeina?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned a previous SSD failure caused him to lose 'a lot of work' and 'old hack code' that was never uploaded to GitHub.
questions: Can you tell us more about the SSD failure? What specific work was lost and how did that impact the project?
What is your backup strategy now? How has that incident changed the way you manage project files and code?

open_questions.context: Kaze passionately advocated for making 'risky' games like the original Yoshi's Island, criticizing the 'safe' approach of many modern titles.
questions: Besides changing the main character's mechanic, what other elements of the original Yoshi's Island do you consider 'risky'?
How are you specifically applying this 'risky' design philosophy to 'Return to Yoshi's Island' beyond just the large overworld concept?
If you were given a large budget and team, what kind of 'risky' game would you create from scratch?

open_questions.topic: Financial Realities of Fan Game Development
open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned needing to make many sponsored videos to 'make money for my family' and expressed disappointment with Twitter's revenue.
questions: How do you balance the need to create sponsored content for income with the time and energy required for a passion project like this?
What are the financial pressures of being a full-time creator working on non-commercial fan projects?
Does the need for sponsorships influence the type of content you create or the development schedule?

open_questions.context: Kaze was highly critical of the original Mario 64 programmers, with the specific exception of a programmer named 'Guile'.
questions: You mentioned 'Guile' did decent work on the original game. What specific work did he do, and how can you tell it's different from the rest of the team's code?
What are some of the most frustrating examples of 'bad code' you've encountered in the Mario 64 engine that made your work harder?
